text: anyone who's ever been on a diet and has
said that they cannot eat chocolate cake
knows full well that they then start
thinking about wanting and moving
towards chocolate cake every day we have
lots of goals and lots of activities and
often what we do is we start trapping
ourselves into half to language when we
feel that we have to do something our
brains rebel we become attracted to the
very thing that we are trying to avoid
so it might be that you are trying to
lose weight because your spouse is at
you to lose weight or because you feel a
sense of shame at looking like a blip
have two goals that are generated by a
sense of obligation or shame actually
ramp up temptation and lead us to do the
very thing that we don't want to do when
you have a have to go and you see the
chocolate cake your brain has already
decided that that chocolate cake is what
you are eating a what to goal in
contrast to have to goal is a goal that
is driven by an internal intrinsic
desire that is of value and connected
fundamentally with what we want so with
health behaviors I have to go to lose
weight might be I've got to lose weight
because my spouse is at me to lose
weight
whereas I want to go might be I truly
want to live to see my children grow up
I want to go actually ramps down
temptation you are likely to see the
chocolate cake but to also see every
else in the fridge and to not be
heightened and focused on that chocolate
cake and wanting to eat it
